div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

THE GREATEST care should be taken in what we eat and drink, yet we are too often indifferent and careless, notwithstanding health depends on what we eat and drink.

In regard to drink nothing but the best should be taken. It costs no more than the indifferent quality, if people would only ask for what they know is the best Old Scotch Whisky is the most wholesome beverage yet known Mackie's Scotch Whisky gives an undoubted guarantee to those who are not judges of quality.
CITY ANALYSTS LABORATORY,
138 BATH STREET,
GLASC0W, 8th October, 1906.

I hereby certify that I have taken samples of every vatting of Mackie's White Horse Celler Blend of Scotch Whisky used in bottling during the month of September, and the results of my analyses indicate that it conforms to the standard for Pot Still Scotch Whisky set up in the London case. div.head: DE GUERVILLE v. DICEY.
div.p: Remarkable as it is that views so diametric | ally opposed as those expressed in Mr. Dicey's

book "Egypt of the Future" and M. de Guer| ville's article in the "Fortnightly Review should appear within a few days of each other, it is still more worthy of notice that the conclusions arrived at by a Frenchman should

commend themselves to those most qualified to I judge as being far more in accordance with fact than the opinions formed by an Englishman, especially one so well-known as M. Dicey. It is indeed strange that an to Egypt, of all places in the world, a French author should show so decidedly superior a capacity to gauge the extent of the success achieved by the policy of the British Agent, and have the frankness to publicly admit the benefits that British rule have conferred upon the country. In the book that he published last year ("New Egypt") M. de Guerville gave convincing proof that, clever as he was in picquant description of the gay doings of the Cairo season, he was equally capable of dealing with the more serious problems of Egyptian life. None but a very careful observer of what is going on could have shown so intimate an acquaintance with the land question for instance; probably, however, the predominance of the lighter vein prevented to a great extent a due appreciation of the more solid portions of the book, to which the article in the "Fortnightly" forms a fitting sequel.

It appears to us to be somewhat late in the day to raise, as Mr. Dicey has done, the question of Lord Cromer's "system of autocratic rule administered by British officials appointed by himself and holding their offices subject, in fact though not in name, to his approval." It ever a policy, of what our contemporary "The Evening Standard" calls "benevolent autoera. cy" hus been justified by the results attendant upon it, that of Lord Oromer is certainly the most conspicuous in success that we can call to mind. Incidentally Mr. Dicey admits that the autocratic system "is the same under which Egypt has been ruled for ages,' seemingly oblivious of the fact that it would be useless to attempt to govern Eastern people by any other I method than that to which long use had accus tomed them. But Lord Cromer's autocratic rule has not only been benevolent, it has gone far | beyond that, and has been so liberal and toler ant that he has been frequently reproached for giving far too great opportunity for the growth of native discontent. Mr. Dicey's description of the Anglo-Egyptian official and Lord Cromer's wish "to give as little encouragement as possible to any British official who endeavours to ascertain for himself the views and opinions of the Egyptian population," is totally at variance not only with fact, but with the desire expressed by Lord Cromer in his speech to the Skinners' Company in 1908 that "Egypt should be governed in the interests of the Egyptians themselves." One notable result of this speech was that on his lordship's return to this country he was welcomed by one of the leading native newspapers as "one whom Egyptians love," "who likes the peasant, aids the weak, and opposes a determined resistance to the oppression which he bates."

It is pleasant to turn from Mr. Dicey's bitter attack on Lord Oromer to the optimism of M. de Guerville's clear, concise, and far more reasonable statements. Discontent and fanaticism are reduced by him to their true proportions, the tendency to magnify simple quarrels and or linary cases of crime into proofs "that the Mussulman population is in a dangerously inflammable condition," is com mented on. Where Mr. Dicey can only discern that "native ministers in common with all Orientals dislike trouble," the French writer says that "almost the whole of Egypt is hard at work" and that "where formerly laziness reigned supreme, work is to day being pursued, with incredible fervour and energy, while life is as intense as in France or England State ments more at variance than these it is diffi. cult to imagine, but there can be little doubt that while Eastern energy is still far behind Western ideas of what this consists-at any rate in some not unimportant details the example set by Englishmen and the earnestness with which they bave worked to effect the regeneration of Egypt has not been without lits effect on Egyptian officials. On all hands and in every department of industrial and commercial life is the improvement clearly visible

In derling with the disaffection which to a greater or lesser extent certainly exists in Egypt, M, de Guerville. eu umerates the principal elements which go to make up the body of malcontents. In their ranks, he says, "we find the patriots, real or 'sham, whose hearts bleed at the sight of the Englishman giving orders like a master and often somewhat roughly," "the ambitious," the "disappointed" and the irreconcilabl s." While expressing his sympathy with those who wish to see their coun. try free and independent he recognises, as do they themselves generally, that the time has not yet come for this, Egypt being as yet in. capable of self-government.

Very wisely as we think, M, de Guerville attempts no forecast as to the future course of events in Egypt. Doubtless, being a sensible man, he knows that it is dangerous to prophesy unless you know, Heis content to point out that at the present time the country cannot stand alone and that the only suitable support is England, "or rather it is that excellent man Lord Cromer." With this conclusion it is needless to say we cordially agree, and we are rejoiced to think that this vindication of the policy pursued by his lordship should appear at so opportune a moment. His hands want strengthening, not weakening, and the testimony of so enlightened an observer as M. de Guerville has shown himself to be is especially valuable as a set-off to Mr. Dioey's gloomy vatioinations

div.head: Fire at Cotton Shoonah
div.p: Yesterday afternoon a fire was discovered in the cotton press "ex Peel" at Minet elBassal. It was practically extinguished by the employés of the establisbment. Owing to the enormous danger of a fire in this neigbbourhood the whole of the Alexandria Fire Brigade tarp ed out and were on the spot within fourteen minutes of the coll. This promptitude refl-ots great credit in the organisation of our local brigade.

div.head: Walker's Bar on Fire
div.p: Only two years ago the great Alexandrian bar of Messrs. Walker & Meimarachi was oompletely gotted and this morning apain another con flagration broke out there. At 8 80 a m. the Alexandria Fire Brigade were summoned to the Old Bourse Palace and broke into be bar, from wbicb volumes of smoke were i-eding. The fire was only in the counter. Quantities of bottles of spirits borst and bad their cork blows ont from tbe beat bot the fire was easily extinguished by means of three chemical extinguishers

div.head: The Broker and the Belle
div.p: Yesterday tbe Csiro Bourse operations were suspended for half-an-hour asmak of sym. pathy for the sad suicide of M. Negrin. On Friday evening at about 9 o'clock the Ghezireb Palace Hotel was startled at the noise of revol. ver sbote and it was discovered that M. Camel Negrin the young son of M Elie Negrin of Kasr-el-Nil, bad shot bims-fin the bead, desh being instantaneous. The funeral' took place yesterday afternoon. The young man was madly in love with a beautiful American tourist, twenty-two years of age, bot ber parents re. fused to countenance the match The tragedy has put a number of well-known Cairo families in mournir g as the Negrin, Rossi, Jabes, Zag. doop, Mir, Gazi, Viterbo, Cattani, Cbalom

Tickets are to be had at all the principal hotels, at the Maison Hugo Hackh, and at the Kbe divial Opera House itself.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE

Après on débat remarquablement ferme, une petite réaction s'est produite vers la fip. Oo ne pouvait guère s'attendre, en effet, à une réance de hausse pour le dernier jour des liqnidations. Beaucoup de positions contingent à se reporter.
L'Union Foncière a été demandée pendant toute la matinée, mais sans résultat : il n'y a pas de vendeore. Le prix ooté est de 6 1/8 3/16.
Mieux tenog. les Estates d'avancent à 1/32 et les Nu govich Hotels à 80, msis avec peare traparotions.

La National Bank se msiotient a 28 et la Delta Land a 4 1/4. L'Urbside est tant soit peu plus faible a 7 9/16 l'ancienne et 7 1/18 la nouvelle
Parmi les titres nouveady, on a traité l'Uni tod a 17/32, l'Arditi a 17/32 l'action et 26 la fondatenr, la Lovioo a 1 7/32, les Ritz Hotels ** 2 1/82-1/16.

Les valente que nous venons d'énumérer ont formé l'objat principal des transctions et des reports. Bar le reste il y a en peu de flnctuations et de mon vement. La tendance gél érsle est bonne et l'on s'attend a une reprise a bref délai.

div.head: EGYPT IN PARLIAMENT
MORE QUESTIONS
THE SUBJECT OF EDUCATION
div.p: (Gazotto's Special Sorvice.)

LONDON Friday. In answer to a question by Mr. J. M. Robertson in the House of Common, Sir Elward Grey said that it would be seen from Lord Cromer's fort hooming Report that the subject of education in Egypt did not need reopening, but would be discussed by the Government with Lord Cromer.

Replying to another question by Sir Gilbert Parker, Sir Edward Grey said he had no doubt that most educated Egyptians desired that French and English should be taught wberever possible as the commercial languages of the country but in view of the fact that. Arabio was the native language be depreosted giving instruction in sciences in any other languages where it was possible to use Arabic.

The Gobbari Land Syndicate is destin. ed to be one of the most important ventures in the modern history Alexandria's developwent and we congratulate Mr. Fabri on his | appointment to this important position while we condole with the bank in the loss of an excellent employé of twenty four years standing

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.
REMARKS.
Yesterday's weather was variable. Bright and warm in the morning it gradually became bleak and cold with a strong wind, To-day opened bright but the sunshine soon gave way to rain.

div.head: THE GENERAL ASSEMBLY
EGYPTIAN PARLIAMENT DEMANDED
div.p: No less than 120 demanda were brought forward at this morning's sitting of the General Assembly. Their number and length entire'y prevented any business being done and all discussion has been postponed till to-morrow.

We understand that these demands included AD Egyptian Parliament, the teaching of the whole of the Koran in all the kattabe, the establishment of primary schools in every markaz, the reduction of school fees, and others for which we have not space.

div.head: ZIZINIA THEATRE
div.p: The management were well requited for the inclusion of "Lucia di Lammermoor" in the Benson's repertory. One rarely tires of this charming opera of Donizetti, whiob, apart from its delicacy of music, has about it an old world air which sends the imagination travelling over generations of past triomphs. "Age cannot wither," eto, and it still deserves and obtains * good deal more than a suocès d'estime; its oltra operatio methods, its trillos and ca let zse still enlist a favourable, if not ecstatio, reooption. All depends of course opon the title 10'e being filled to a vicety, and we are bapı y to say this was the care last night : Signa. Fiozi's delicate and facile voioe amply filled the oxigencies of this lengthy part. la fact she, alone of our present opera company, is capable of imparting the trae atmosphere, and it is a pleasure to record that ber unfligging efforts were well repaid by a house which made op in enthusiasm what it lacked in numbers. We regret, however, that she was not backed up by a stronger oaste. Sig. Acerbi's Edgardo was fair but pothing very striking, while the Eurico of Sig. D'Albore was wanting in base and warmth. Sig. Contini's powerful bass told to good advantage. The oboras bebaved well, and on the wbole the performance would bave been very er joyable but for the more than usually prazen chattering of the audience, in some of be boxes particularly. We soppose we most jabmit to custom and regard as fashionable what, in a more enlightened miliea, constitutes he acme of bad taste.

div.head: DEATH OF FABRICIUS PASHA
div.p: We regret to announce the death of Pabricias Pasha, wbich took place on Thursday night at his house in Boulac-street, Cairo. The Pasha had long been ill and passed away quietly at 9.80 p.m. The funeral will take place at 10.0 a.m. Saturday.

The late Demetrius Fabricius Pasba was born at Syra in 1847. He studied at Stattgart and later at Vienna, where he practised as an architect. In 1891 he came to Buypt, where be rapidly rose to the front rapk among local arobitects and became architect to H.H. the Kbedive. His principal triumph was the Montagab Palace, the designs for which were drawn op by him. He was also responsible for the mod fications at Abdeen Palace, the National Bank, the Agricultoral Bank, the Savoy Hotel, and the Khedivial Agricultural Society's build. ing at Ghu sireb.

The Bbe live, on heaving of Fabricius Pasha's death, sent one of his A. D. C.'s to express his condolences to the family of the deceased. Nua ber of visits of condolence were paid in the course of Friday by deceased's friends of every nationality.

div.head: AGRICULTURAL SHOW
MESSRS. McLAREN'S EXHIBITS
div.p: Messrs. J. and H. MoLaren, engineers, Leeds, England, exbibit a large assortment of steam plonghing. coltivating and levelling machinery. Messrs. Molaren bave bad nearly 49 years' experience in the manufactors and praotioal working of steam ploughing plants, and as Both members of the firm are at present stay. ing at Shepbeard's Hotel they can be seen by any person interested in steam cultivation. Tbeir long experience and expert knowledge will be gratoitonaly placed at the disposal of any person interested or engaged on the problem of the reclamation and improvement of land.

Messrs. McLaren's exhibit consists of a pair of 30 borse power compound steam ploaghing engines, with steel braokets, steel gearing throngbont, and double speed for the rope. This latter invention is a speciality of Messrs. MoLaren's and is of the greatest importance to the users of the ongines. When they are employ. ed on ordinary work the fast speed can be uned, and in favourable oironmstances an ares of 80 to 40 feddans can be galtivated once over in a day of 10 hours. On the other hand if the land is very hard, or if the engines are required to drive Kassabiehs for levelling the Boil, the second, or slower, speed may be used. This increases the power of the engines enor. mously and enables the engines to do excesrively heavy work, which is quite impossible with single speed engines. It may be farther mentioned with regard to these engines that as all the principal castings are of steel the machines are not only mooh stronger, but proportionatıly lighter in oomparison to their power than any of the old type of engines. For instance, the total weight of MoLaren's double speed 80-borre power engines empty is only 174 tong sach, whereas the weight of the ordinary 20 horse power engines with single speed only is 22 tons. The road wheels are made very wide both back and front, and each engine is fitted with 450 yards of Molaren's best special quality of steel ropes for bauling the implement.
Messrs. McLaren also exhibit a pair of 19horsepower compound s'esm ploogbing engines manofaotured to the order of Ali Rifaat Bey.

They are construoted on the same general principles as the 80 H. P. engines described above. They likewire exhibit an assortment of tnrping cultivators 9-11 and 13 times respectively which are capable of cultivating from 15 to 40 feddans per day, according to the power of tbe engines employed and the Dature and quality of the land. These cu tivators can be fitted with ridging bodies, which are also on exbibition, by mouse of which the land is laid op in ridges for cotton, sagar, or irrigation perposer.

Bat the most important and most interesting of Mesars, MoLaren's exhibits is their new patent Kassabieb, wbich promises to work a evolution in levelling land for irrigation. This le.rge machine is made to take in a width of a pont 18 fet, and its capacity is 47 metres cibe each charge. It is formed like an ordinary 80:00p, and is polled by a powerful ploughing engine placed at 006 side of the ground to be levelled. The scoop can be lowered into filling porition any moment by the attendant simply moving a lever. It is bauled forward by the eagide ontil it is full of soil or sand. There tho esgine is stopped and another engine at the opposite side of the ground begins to baul it in the opposite direction. The first effect of the pall of this engine is to raise the scoop into a carrying position, where it is firmly held by a osteh antil it arrives at the place where the load is to be emptied. Here by another move. nient of a lover by the attendant the scoop is tipped completely over; the contents are deposited on the ground and can be spread to Apy tbiekness that may be required from one inoh opwarde. The working of this machine is 80 perfect and satisfactory that Prince Harrein Kamel Pasbs, president of the Khedivial Agricaltaral Society, bas already parobased the one on exbibition at the Show. The Wardan Estates Company, Ltd, have purcbased six, Mergre. Zagdon Freres in the Payoum have purchased two, Mr. Angelo Capsto one, &c. &c. In order that visitors may perfectly Duderstand the working of this enormous implement, Meesrg. M Laren bave on their stand a working model by means of which spectators will be able to 190 clearly bow the various operations are carried out.

The main advantages of this implement are that the power reqnired to transport the soil in the scoop which is carried on large rollers is 1988 than one half of what is reqrired by the ordinary kassabeia which drags the material along the ground, and consequently the cost of the work is correspondingly redu sed.
The exhibits on this stand alone reprerent a value of £5,500 ac i will amply repay the carefal inspection of all interested in the Agrioul. taral walfare of Egypt.

The eight runners gnt off to a good start Nibh with Casino showing the way; on torning the corner the whole with the exception of the Nipper ran in close order and entering the the straight a hard atragle took place, ending to the surprise of many, in the victory of the outsider Bedier by a neck.

div.head: ARMY NOTES
div.p: London, February 21, | Major A.8. Koo, and Battalion the King's Own Boottish Borderers, has taken ap the command of the Depot Companies at Borwiok for the asual period of two years.

Captain G. C. M. Sorel Cameron, Queen's Owa Cameron Highlanders, on retorning bomo from Erypt, where he was employed as President of the Babr-el Ghosal Recruiting Commission, has taken over a company in the lat Battalion at Dablin.
The following officers in Brypt have passed be examination for promotion: Lieptenant and

djatant L E. G. Oates, 6b Ioniskilling Dragoods (since promoted); Captains J.A. Byre, 8. G. Roe, and D. Mathers, Royal Inni-killing Pasiliers; Captain and Brevet Major P. Maclear, Royal .Dablin Pasiliers.

The details of the lat Battalion Royal Ioniskillings have jast arrived at Salisbary Plain from Belfast. The details, which are under Mujør H.P. Hancox, who was recently in special employment at the War Offise, will be attacbed to the Provisional Battalion, Tidworth, till the arrival bome of the 2nd Battalion from Cairo.

The Army Cognoil has jnst laid very explicit rales down for the re-admission of Reservists for service with the colours. Reservista ma rale will only be permitted to rejoin if they can be made available for draft porposes, or if the home unit is short of older soldiers. Por draft requirements, the Reservist should in all CANBS, where the linked unit is in lodia, be able to give four years' service, including the extra year to which he is liable, while for the Culopies, Egypt, sto., three years as a rale should soffice. In no case will married men be allowed to rejoin.

The introduction of Mr. Haldane's famous army of 100,000 men has been delayed by the important fact that before he onn got his 30,000 Militia, Yeomanry, and Volunteers to completo that foroe, the law must be altered. The auxiliary forces car not be sent overses against their wishes, and op to the present they have always volonteered in sufficient numbers, when the exigencies of the service demanded it. A bill will therefore have to be passed before Mr. Haldane's army becomes an accomplished fact, on paper.

div.head:
FEHIM PASHA SCORES
LIVING IN LUXURY

div.p: Fabim Pasha is living in a laxarious manner at Brossa. He is treated with the utmost dis. tination. The diplomats here are indignant.
(Touter)

General Botha's Ministry has been recast and will be sworn in on Monday. Mr. Smuts will be Chief Seoretary and Acting Attorney. Gonoral, Mr. Holl, Treasurer, Mr. De Villiers, Secretary for the Mines, and Mr. Rigsik, Secretary of Agriculture.
(Reuter)

Parliament has agreed to the National Bank advancing the Government 2,000,000 Tomans, two-fitths of which are to be payable this month for the payment of the army, eto. The Bank will epoaab all Government receipts, obarging a commission. 200,000 Tomans from the Persian Gulf Customs receipts will be paid to the Bank yearly for amortization and interest.
(Reuter)

The Government has paid compensation for the sinking of the German steamer Tertaro, with cargo of railway sleepers, by the oroiser Rion. The claims for the British steamers Oldhamia, Ikona, and Knight Commander are still ansettled. The Russian troops to-day evacuated Teitsibar.
(Router)
The engineer Reymond, who is M. Lepine's son-in-law, and managed » factory in Russia, has been murdered by a workman on strike who had been dismissed. (Havas
The King has left for Lisbon. (Havas,
The Magbzed bas agreed to the appointment of Colonel Muller ås Police Commandant in Moro000.
(Havas)
To-morrow's elections for the London Coup ty Counoil are exciting interest almost equal to parliamentary elections.

The main issue turns on the financial and Boonomio polioy of the present Progressive majority. Party politics are largely interminglod thorowith. The Ugionists are strenuously supporting municipal reformers against the 80-called wastrels.
(Reuter)

An Admiralty memorandum explains that the Nore division of the new Home Fleet will consist of six battlesbips and six armoured oruisers oompletely manned. They will never loa vo bomo waters and will be constantly ready for any emergency
(Router)
The deaths are reported of Colonel Sir Henry Hozier, late Secretary of Lloyd's, Sir Francis Plankett, the Marobioneas of Ripon, and the American writer Mr. Wendell Garrison. (R)

div.head: NEW EGYPTIAN COMPANY LTD.
REPORT OF DIRECTORS
div.p: in Bephs of payment company and
The following is the report of the directors of the above company, to be submitted to the sixth ordinary general meeting of sharebolders to be held in London on the 8th inst. :

The directors beg to submit to the share. holders the balance sbeet and profit and loss account made up to the 31 th June, 1906, and have pleasure in stating that the company's land investments sbow a steady and continuous increase in valoe ; the areas under reclamation on the Nile are gradually extending, the rentals per feddan are steadily improving, and business in the Sudan and on Lake Mer zsleh is opening up in a very satisfactory manner. The profit and loss account shows a credit balance of £3,262 68. Id., sofficient to have permitted of the distribution of a 5 per cent. dividend, bat, baving regard to the engagements of the company and the protractod terms of payment stipulated for by buyers ia Egypt, your directors do not recommend any distribution for the present. They consider it in the interests of the company to maintain a strong fioanoial position pending realisations which it is not desirable to press. If, however, Degotiations now proceediog for the sale of some of our properties are successfully conclud. ed, the directors hope to be at once in a position to declare an interim dividend. The directors have again made a valuation of the land and sbare assets shown in the balance sheet |(xclusive of land now in process of reglamation), based as far as possible on the market quotations and on offers actually received for some of the land, which shows an appreciation over cost price much in excess of the £100,000 estimated in last year's report. The value of the reclaimed land now appears to be well atured, and the profit to be realised trom this 898et should reach a very important figure.

LANDS PURCHASED FROM THE DAIRA SANIEH.-- No further sales of these lands have been nade daring the year ander review, although A number of off are have been received. The large estate at Mstaans, comprising 3,457 feddane, of wbioh four-fifths belong to the com pany, has been let out for the current season at rentals of about £21,000. The recently reported sale of neighbouring land at £90 per feddan also indicates a farther increase in the realisable value of this property over the price, £55 per feddan, at which the company por obased it three years ago. For the remaining 48 feddans in the Matai district offers of £150 per feddan bave been refused, a portion of the land being suitable for catting ap into bnilding plots. The Kolossda property, consisting of 622 teddans, has recently been consolidated by *n exchange of plots with a neighbouring landowner, and should now be more readily saleable at a price much higher than its very moderate Bost.

OTHER AGRICULTURAL LANDS. - The oompany has acquired a block of agricultural land Dear Nashart, in the Garbieb distriot of Lower Egypt, comprising about 700 feddans. When certain improvements-now in course of execu. tion-have been completed, it is anticipated that it will be saleable at a considerable profit, especially it sold in small plots on easy terms of payment

NILE LAND RECLAMATION WORKS — These, wbiob continue vader the supervision of Mr. Beresford, the company's consulting engineer, have acted well during 1906. The flood, thongh still not quite up to the average, was the best experienoed for several years, and the increased area let out for the present season indicates the material advance which has been made in reclamation at the various sites.
The following table shows, as in last year's report, the extent of the company's interests at the sites so far taken op, including the land parohased in connection therewith
Bstimated Area. Area. Name of Site. Reclaimable, Purebased. Total Area.
Feddads. Feddans. Peddans. Sobag. 420
420 Gari Sarban. 490
182 Rodah. 890
219 609 Sbeikh Fadl. 360
360 Saadat. 605
500 Hataba 405 173 578 Asbmant
390 790 (land bought in Kolosspa. view of future
Total teddans. 3,570

The total outlay on account of these 5,441 feddang, reclaimable or purchared, amounted on the 30th June, 1906, to £159,818 or, £29 7s.6d per feddan. This low cost indicates eventual realisation of large profite as the works approach completion. Io the meantime the rents received from these lande sbow a steady and satisfactory increase, the net re. ceipts from this source during the last three years being :

, 1905-1906... ... 5,741 With regard to the qnestion of the renewal of the reslamation concorsion, which has been onder disonssion with the Egyptian Governmert for the past two years, the test case men tioned in the last report has now been beard before the Mixed Tribanale, but judgment has not yet been rendered. Pending this decision, which will bave an important bearing on the negotiations, your directors consider it in advisable to make any statement on the subjeot.
(To be continued)
The Directors, while reserving themselves discretion in the allotment of shares, will endeavour as far as possible to allot PRO RATA to the applications received.
Eaoh subsoriber for the Ordinary Shares will be entitlod to apply for and reoelve an allotment at par, of Five Deferred Sharo. In roopoot of
every oomplete 100 Ordinary Shares allotted to suoh subsorlber. The Subscription List will be opened on the 7th March 1907, and closed at or
before Noon on the 9th March 1907. This prospectus has been filed with the Registrar of J. int Stock Companies.

The Ordinary Shares will be entitled to a Preferential Dividend of 5 per bent, and will participate with the Deterr.d Shares in the remaining profits available for distribution; the 0 dinary Shares taking 60 per cent, and the Deferred the remaining 40 per cent. The Directors have together subscribed for 28,250 Ordinary shares, which will be allotted at par.

div.head: ABRIDGED PROSPECTUS
div.p: This Company has been formed for the porposes set out in its Memorandum ot Association, and specially to carry on Hotel Basin888 in Egypt and the Sudan.

The Company will, by adopting a Contract with option set out below, acquire the Business of the Windsor Hotel at Alexandris, as a going concern, together with the Parniture, Pittings and Goodwill, and the Lease of the Premises (which bas Ten more Years to ran) for Four Yesrs with a preferential option for the remaining Six Years thereof.

The present Windsor Hotel, on account of its unique position facing the sea, and the able management, is ondoubtedly one of the most popular and succesful establiebments of the kind in Ezypt. It was founded in 1902, and has since then steadily inerented in siz potil in 1906 it had doabled the number of its goest rooms, of which it now contains 65. The employ. ment of more Capital in manner proposed by the Directors is necessary now in order to giva full soope to tbat expansion to which the business itself shows a natural te denoy.
The Vendors agree to take ba'f of the Parchase Price of £81,000 as shown in the Contract referred to below, in Fully Paid op Ordinary Shares of the Company

The Founders and Proprietors of the Hotel, who have brought it up to its present 8000088, will continue the Management for the Company; Mr. Aug. van Milliogen being appointed General Manager. As remuneration for their services, they agrer, in lieu of fixed salary, to receive together 15% of the gros9 profits as set out in the Contract mentioned below. They will hold their appointment for 5 years, and will daring that time together retain not less than 5.000 Ordinary Bhares in the Company
The Vendors further undertake never in future to embark apon any Hotel Enterprise in Egypt.

The present botol premises are beld on lease from Mohammed Effendi Abdel Halek Heddaya and Mustafa Bey Taban of Alexandris by a contraot of lease at a Revtal of £1000 per appom, registered at the Mixed Tribunals of Alexandris on the 30th October 1902, and containing a toll snb-letting classe. The lessee, one of the Vendors above stated, Mrs. Van Millingen, née Charrel, covenants to sub-lease, as stated in the contracts No. 1 set out below, for the same consideration as the rent payable by bar to the above lensors.

The accounts ma le op by M388rs. R 1Rel!, Kerr and Wyatt, Chartered Accountante, of Alexandria, xbow that the business of the Windsor Hotel bas produced an approximate net profit of £2.142 for 1905 and £3,658 for 1906.
The Company will therefore porless going ooncern working at a profit, which should enable a dividend for the first year to be distributed on the amount of paid op Capital.
In order, bowev.-r, to provide for the expansion of the business, a suitable plot of land - on the Esst Harbour Qisys of Alexandris near the present premises has been secured at very

advantageous terms, as shewn in the Contract -No. 2. set out below. It is intended to put op a larger building with all the modern onnveniences and improvements of a first olass botel, containing Restaurant, Grillroom, Refreshment Bar, Café, Entertainment Hall, eto.
With the rapidly increasing prosperity of Bypt and the expansion of Alexandria as a business centre, a large increase in the business is anticipated.
When the new hotel bas been started it in proposed to give attention to the development of hotei bosines generally in the other principal towns of Beyot and the Sondan
The minimum snbscription npin which the Directors mav prooed to allotment is fixed by the Articles of Association at 10% of the number of Shares offered for so beoription.

The Directors are interested in the formation of the Company thus: Mr. Aogostus van Millingen is interested as Vendor io half of the business acquired by the Company as mentioned in Contract No. 1 set out below. In addition to that, he has agred to subscribe for 5,650 Ordinary Shares at par and has onderwritten 16,000 Ordinary Shares. M. Loutfi Ayroat Bey and M. Victor K. Naggar have together agreed to subscribe 14,125 Ordinary Shares at par and have onderwritten together 40,000 Ordinary Sh488.
Mr. W. B. Rees bas agreed to subscribe 5,650 Ordinary Shares at par and bas apdor written 16,000 Ordinary Shares.
Mr. H. E. Maltans bas agreed to subscribe 1,41% Ordinary Shares at par and bas underwritten 4,000 Ordinary Shares.
Mr. E. &. C. Mose has agreed to subscribe 1,418 Ordinary Shares at par and has | underwritton 4,000 of the Ordinary Sharon.
There will be no underwriting commission payable in cash by the Company
The consideration for the above mentioned goderwritiog is the right to absoribe at Par and pay for the proportions of Deferred Shares stated in Contract No. 1 set ont below.

The Direotors are also interested as saberibers at par for 4,680 Datorred Share in manner and proportion stated in the Contract No. I set ont below, in consideration of their services, outlay aud risk as promoters of the Company.
The amount estimated for prelimioary expenses payable by the Company under Contract No. 1 set out below is £2,000, in addition to the brokerage beresfrer mentioned.
A brokerage of 3d. per share will be paid on all Ordinary Sbares allotted in respect of public applications hearing Brokers' stamps.

div.head: BENGER'S Food
div.p: For Infants, Benger's Food solves the problem of hand-rearing. It contains all the elements necessary to healthy development in infancy.

div.head: BOVRIL
div.p: Qu'est ce que c'est BOVRIL?
BOVRIL est le produit garanti du meilleur bétail qui existe.
C'est un repas à la minute qui protège contre les intempéries.
"BOVRIL" et "Bonne Cuisine" sont deux mots qui disent la même chose.

BOVRIL répond a une nécessité; il est non seulement une boisson delicieuse et saine, mais il est encore indispensable pour préparer instantanement des soupes et sauces appétisantes. Bovril n'a pas de rival pour corser les plats les plus récherches.
BOVRIL répare l'organisme fatigué.

div.head: REVUE COMMERCIALE
Cotone
div.p: Ce serait de la bien mauvaise grâce de notre part que de venir contester ou simplement de vouloir ergoter sur la valeur des évèvements de la remaine, en grande partie inattendus, et sur leurs conséq ences, car les faits matériels, à tort ou à raison, sont là contre nous et nous furoent à reconnaitre que pour le moment les cho-es, dans leur ensemble, ont été à l'encontre de nos idées. Nous le déclarons, mais Eane toutefois faire amende honorable, comme l'acraient voulu qne'ques lecteurs, bons enfants au fond, msis grincheux et prétendant avoir toujours raison, et cela parce que nous oro yons qu'après tout nous finirons par prendre une revanche partielle ; seulement, nous demandons aussi, comme ficbe de consolation, pour la non réalisation jusqu'ici de nos pronostics sur le Mars, qu'on nous donne acte de ce que, ce qui s'est passé sur le Novembre avait été, bien prévu par nong,

On nous reprochers peut être que nous y mettons do l'entêtement ou que vous faisons montre d'amour-propre piqué au jeu en exprimant toujours l'espoir dans l'avenir : ce sera ce que l'on voudra, mair, d'autre part, les adver. Baires de nos idées doivent bien admettre qu'il aurait falla etre réellement prophète, né ier bien difficile que celui-là, pour prévoir qu'à force de Livres Sterling la spéculation aurait persévéré dans ses erremente, comptant toujours pouvoir les réparer par la suite !
Ceci dit en guise d'introduction passons à la revue da marobé.,

Sans le moindre motif pon vant servir d'en. couragement ni looal ni da dehors; au contraire, avec des raisons toutes en faveur de la baisse, soit grosses recetter, petites exportations pour commencer et faiblesse en Amérique, la semaine a débuté en basse et cela à la suite des rachats de la spéculation cairote de ses ventes sur Novembre. Le découvert a été contesté, il est vrai, par quelques courtier , qui probablement n'étaient pas logés à la même enseigne que leurs confrères, mais, on réalité, il existait et il provenait pon seulement des ventes faites en blano, mais anesi des soi-disapt opérations d'arbitrage en Mars et Novembre. En tous cas, Op qni est indéniable, c'est que les ordres d'achst sur la nouvelle récolte et ceux de vente en Mars ont plu en mee temps et cou me les quantités sur lesquelles on voulait opé.er étaient colossales, on saisit facilement que de telles affaires ne pouvaient etre exécatéos 8808 prodoire un mouvement marqué sur les prix, comme da reste cela a été le cas.

Le premier effet de ses opérations a été une basse plas sensible sur le Novembre que sur Je Mars, car le premier était plus demandé que le dernier n'était offert ; mais à la spite des réalisations qui ont pu lies et des énormes transferts sor Mai consentis moyennant la prime de 3/4 & 7/8 de tallari, circonstance qui a facilité la besogoe, on retour de faveur a eu lieu sur le Mars et en définitive c'est sur la cote de 29 5/8 pour Mars et 20. 17/32 pour le Novembre que la semaine a fini, ce qi nous fait en définitive et respectivement 3/4 et 7/8 de ha088e.

Cela est bead, incontestablement, et d'autant plus qu'il n'y a presque pas en de réactions même intérimaires et que le progrès « 616 constant et gradael, mais si la position de la vieille récolte semble pour le moment dégagée, ou plos exactement en grande partie rédaite, il n'en est pas moins vrai cependant qu'il y a Bocore pas mal de flottant qui pourrait de nonveau peser sur la sitnation, m»lg é toutes les assertions qu'il y aura des récepti ne de Mars. Nous de contestons pas l'information en ellemême, mais nous disoutous le ch ftce qui sera TEG1, car an topil, il ne s'rgit que d'une on deux personnes, dont les moyens leur permet. tent de re sonstraire à l'obligation de payer les reports demandés actnellement.

En l'espèce done, il ne s'agit pullement de ocups de spéculation, visant un égorgement quelor nque, mais simplement d'une quantité Imitée, ayant qualité commerciale, et qni de modifierait en rien la eituation même. S'il ya da flottant, les retardatsires spéonlateors en papier, n'auront qu'à se reporter, autrement, s'ils se mettent vendre, ils an. ront toutes les chances de ne pas trouver d'acheteurs. C'est pour cette raison que nous disons qne la question de Mars n'est pas encore fioie, quoiqne, après tout, les cborer pourraient bien se passer le plus pac fique ment dã monde et en lais ant tout l'inté e d'ici peu de jours, se concentrer sur la Mi
Da reste, c'est & dels que nous devour aboutir, étant donné que ce n'est pas pour des Defles que la spoulation a payé les gros
anorte, mais bien pour gagner les 60 jours le répit qui, à sa manière de voir, doivent
i donner tout le loisir de manipuler le harché pour arriver à forcer la main à la filature. La réursite est dans le domaine da Dossible, mais ce qni semble plus probable,

'est qne le Msi prendra la place da Mars; à bref délai, et qne comme résultat défiuitit d'ext d'one liqnidation plus ou moics torcée que l'on arrivera, étant donné que beaucoup d'arbitragistes sont décidés à ne consentir socon report pour juillet

Telles semblent 8're da moins les idées do moment; cela n'exclat certes pas on ebange. ment éventuel d'opinion, mais ce qui est plus important et au-dessus de tout, c'est que sans la filature venant au secours, l'issue fi ale ne saurait être brillante et somme toate ce ne serait, pour les baissiers, que partie remise.

La semaine s dié d'une activité extraordi. psire et certaines séances ont représenté des centaines de milliers de captars de transaotions. Le Novembre a pent être éé plas miné qne Mars; dans tous les cas il a permis à ceux qu'on blogisit et qui détenaient les plus fortes quantié de contrats Novembre de sortir on de s'alléger d'ape façon admirable. A ce point de vne, Meror di a éé la joorsée onlminante, tandis que Juodi a été peut-être la journée la meios ardente et cela à cause de quelques offres de vente sur les réponses des primes qui devaient se donner le soir.

Maintenant, on point à signaler : l'intérieur vend sbr la prochaine récolte d'une façon plus libérale, le gros prix actuel étant bien tentant, et cette circonstance pourrait bien ralentir l'ardoor de la spéculation sur le Novembre et om @cher peut-être tout le rapproobement qu'on avrait voula entre la récolte actuelle et la nouvelle et qui aurait été le seul moyen d'induire la filature à nous débarrasser de nos vieux cotons.
En tous cas, au niveau présent do Novembre une baisse réellement sérienre n'est pas probable sur la vieille récolte, à moins de quelqne chose d'imprévo.

Pour ce qni est de la filature oos jours-oi, les Acbats qu'elle a pu faire, en prompt, ne valent presque pas la peine d'one mention ; elle a mé é on peu plus largement sur le Novembre, nais il y a lieu de se mettre en garde contre en broite qui'o fait courir qu'il y aurait déjà le 1,540,000 À 2,000,000 de Cantare de rendus !!

Comue monvement de la réc lte nous marchons incontestablement sur les 7,000 000 de Cantars et d'acoons disent même que ce cb ftre sera dépassé. D'ailleurs, demain même nous aurops atteint 6 1/2 et il y a 8000re pas mal de coton dans l'intérieur. Le solde à vendre, serait donc encore très important et fait dispara Itre toate orainte d'insuffiance de coton d'ici la prochaine récolte. La filature pourrait tout arbetar quand même mais il est certain qu'elle ne sorsit tout consommer. Filant en moyenne plus fio que d'habitude, avant meil. leur rendement à 40-e de l'exo allenos de la qualité de cette année et les heures de travail étant partout légalement limi'ée, les broobes en activité ne peuvent pas tout manger 1 On finirs par s'apercevoir que malgré l'augmentation du nombre de filstores employant nos 00*one, la matière première aura été plus qu'abondante : | L9 marché du disponible a marqué d'6'asti

cité comme sffaires : Si les vendeurs sont fermes dans leurs prétentions, de l'autre côté i aussi les acbeteurs de montrent pas de l'entrain et nr torellement cela se résume en un manque d'activité a88fz margné.

Comme exportations, nous avons eu une véritable surprise : le total de la semaine a atteint 28.00 Balles, contre 25,000, ce qui rédoit toute la diminution du février en la mois correspondant en 1906 à 5 % en tout ! On explique le fait par des embarguments "Anticipés sur les ventes Mars, tant à cause de

Une seule fois enffit.
Liverpool' a continné à fouroir à notre marebé an appoi efficace avec ses ventes rela
ivement importantes en égyptions dieponibles et avec la continuation de la hausse sur nos

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIERE
div.p: Le flot des nouvelles émissions a paralyse ce mois-ci la ropri e habituelle qui se produit en février ; mais c'est le cas de dire qne ce qui est différé d'est pas perde, car l'avenir da marché se presente sous un aspect l'autant plus rassurant que les motifs de la baisse de sont on mystère pour personne, pas plus que les oirconstances favorables de natore à déterminer à bref délai one reprise potable, au moine sur les bonnes valeurs de placement. Comme obaoon le sait, les nouvelles sociétés fondées depuis le mois de novembre et celles en voie de formation ont exercé un effet déprimant sur notre place, en immobilisant des sommes énormes, destinées aux valeura. Notre spéculation, friande d'émotions et à l'affat de primes problématiques, a venda les titres Folides qu'elle possédait pour affecter ses disponibités aux entreprises nouvelles dont quelques-unes sont excellentes sans doute, mais dont beaucoup offrent un grand alés, comme cela résulte des cours d'un grand nombre d'entre elles qui se trouvent aotoellement sous le pair. Les établie sements de crédit, se ressentant de oe drainage de numéraire, et inquiets peut être des manipalations basardées auxquelles se livre la spéouletion, opponent au torrent des lanceurs d'affsires lear force d'inertie, on réclamant une angments tion de marge et de consentantqne difficilement à accorder de nouvelles avaDoes - ur titren. A 008 OADres principales de malaire vient s'ajuter la toute des marchés européens qui a été rien moins qne sa'isfaisante. Hatons-nous d'ajouter qu'an mieux sensible s'est produit bier tant sur le consolidé anglais et la rente française que sur les valeurs égyptiennes. Sane vouloir préjoger de cette amélioration, que nous arnonnoions depois quelque temps, on est bien obligé de reconnaitre que la cote a atteint pour nos valeurs de placement on niveso de dépréciation qu'il leur sera d fficile de dépasser, en mettant les choses au pire, ce qui n'est pas le cas. Nous ne craignons pas de dire qu'au contraire tout semble militer en faveur d'une reprise pour le mois de mars.
La semaine qui vient de s'écouler a été on grande partie consacrée aux reports. Les affaires proprement dites ont dono en pen d'importance.
I Quant aux fluctuations, elles indiq net on

état à peu près stationnaire : 15 titres sont en hausse, 20 en baisse et les autres demeurent Bade changement. div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list shewing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:—
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 14 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers of the P.& O., the Egyptian Mail S.S,. Co., North German Lloyd, Orient, and Messageries Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, Bibby and Henderson Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said can now be made without change in 4 ½ hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.

The quickest through Continental routes are by P.& O. Brindisi express from Port Said, by the Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., from Alexandria to Marseilles and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe. The Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., have also made arrangements whereby luggage can be collected and sent to any address.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves Port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna, and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; here there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Domino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea. No hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza.

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of Lake Maggiore, has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse.

THUN (on the Lake of Thun) half an hour from Berne and one hour from Interlaken. Quiet and quaint; sheltered from winds; just the place to rest and recuperate. Beautiful walks, through woods, and along the lake shore. Kursaal, Concernts, Casino, Races, Tennis, Boating, etc.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND. – INTERLAKEN, a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees, the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

ZURICH on the Gothard route. Direct communication with Northern Europe. Largest town in Switzerland, beautifully-situated on the lake of Zurich. Theatres. Big Concern Halls. Boating on the lake. Excellent schools. The National Museum.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

From Venice or Lido, charming trip on the lagoon, 12 min. by steamboat. CLIMATIC STATION AND SEA BATHS, WITH CHINESITHERAPIC INSTITUTE. Express between the station and Lido for the Hotels.

The most important bathing station in Italy, Café-Restaurant and Terrace on the sea. Hydrotherapic Institute, Concerts daily. Frequented by the highest classes of society.
GRAND HOTEL DES BAINS.
Adjoining the sea. First-class hotel with dependencies & Chalets. 200 rooms & saloons. Electric light. Aqueduct. Every modern comfort. Delightful residence, without any mosquitos.
THE GRAND HOTEL, LIDO .

Hotel with its dependencies (Swiss Hotel) in the most delightful situation of the Lido at the landing place, five minutes walk from the bathing place. Wonderful view of the Lagune of Venice. Room from 3 lire, with board from 8.50 per day. No mosquitos. Very dry and safe air.
Address-SOCIETE BAGNI. LIDO, VENICE ITALY

div.head: SALSOMAGGIORE (Italy.)
div.p: A pleasantly situated village lying in the valley between Piacenza and Parma, rapidly becoming famous for its waters, which are very rich in bromine and iodine and the richest in the world in lithium, strontium, and ichthyol, and have been successfully used in the treatment of scrofula, rheumatism, tuberculous affections, ladies complaints, etc.
